options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lecture that was not recorded.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is helpful in terms of learning more French grammar skills such as the subjunctive, relative pronouns, literary grammar, faire causatif, etc. This course focuses a lot on grammar work within the course packet, and from all the grammar work your French will improve. Additionally, you also practice your writing in short responses (300-500 words) and you will practice your oral speaking for in-class activities and also for tests.

My ability to speak and write French obviously developed a great deal. We also learned in class about the French diaspora, engaging with works of literature from many different Francophone places, something which I truly enjoyed. I also felt like I was now, much more than before, able to take my normal literary analysis skill that I use to understand English texts and apply that to French texts as well.

I learned and developed my French grammar. We really solidified the grammar I had learned in high school and learned even more. I also read French novels for the first time, which greatly increased my reading comprehension skills.
I furthered my knowledge in french grammar as well as expanded my knowledge of many cultures around the world.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course does a great job of supplying you with a lot of grammar work in addition to writing and oral practice. However, within the grammar work, a lot of the grammar that is taught is grammar that isn't widely used in the language, such as literary grammar. Aside from that, this course does a really good job of engaging you during activities and discussions.
Overall, I think the course was excellent. The pace was very good, and Madame Koundi was a really clear and enthusiastic instructor. Frankly, I can't really think of any weaknesses.

Strengths - Prof Koundi was very energetic and passionate. She made class enjoyable even though it was every day. I liked the texts that we read; they were actually interesting. The tests were very fair. 
Weaknesses - I thought the workload would be way worse than it actually was, and it ended up being very manageable except for when we had to read Un Sac de Billes. We had like 40-60 pages of reading each night plus vocabulary to do, plus reading comprehension questions, and it was really overwhelming and time consuming. I wish Un Sac de Billes had been more spaced out like La Symphonie Pastorale. I wish we worked more on speaking.
Professor Koundi is very intelligent and knows many insights about the French language, yet the workload was sometimes a bit overdone

The course packet for the course explains and covers the grammar material with great detail. In order to improve, I believe having extra worksheets for grammar topics would be useful. For studying and further understanding, I found that I didn't have as much practice as I would have liked.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, the course succeeded over Zoom. Discussions were still fluid, we were able to correct assignments in class, and we were also able to properly complete and submit homework.

Overall, I believe the class adapted quite well to COVID. Because it was a seminar-style and called for a great deal of student participation, it was easier to feel engaged. OWL, our test-taking format, was also quite effective.

The professor utilized the whiteboard function which I found was really useful when she was explaining examples. We were also put into breakout rooms that would constantly change so I was able to meet and discuss with everyone in my class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this class. In this course, you will improve your French through your grammar, speaking, and writing. While it is more work than other classes, it is worth it as you definitely improve your French. Professor Koundi is also great and is engaging during the course.
I would! I believe I learned a great deal, and I had a really fun time while doing it.
Yes I would. Dont be scared by the reviews about the workload because it really is manageable. This was probably my favorite class I took this semester, even though it was every day.

I would recommend this course since I found that I learned a lot and was able to really practice my french discussions while having the perfect balance of grammar with literary studies and culture exploration. I learned so much during this class and really enjoyed myself.
